data.body:
We need to develop a set of guidelines for users helping with MonoGame API reference documentation.

The guidelines should include some simple bullet points as to things documentation writers should address in class, method, and parameter docs.

The guide should be maintained in the wiki.

data.title: Kindlefirefix
data.body:
Because the Kindle Fire devices default orientation is flipped by 180 degrees from all the other android devices on the market we need to do some special processing to make sure that LandscapeLeft is the correct way round. 

If you don't believe this 

https://developer.amazon.com/sdk/fire/best-practices.html#SettingOrientation

"For a device with a default orientation of portrait, both ROTATION_90 and ROTATION_270 result in a landscape orientation. The default landscape orientation for the Kindle Fire (1st Generation) and Kindle Fire (2nd Generation) is ROTATION_90. The default landscape orientation for the Kindle Fire HD tablets is ROTATION_270. "

Thanks to the hitcents guys for testing this fix out in draw a stick man. 
I put this setting the the AndroidCompatability class as we will probably need to use this setting in the accelerometer to flip values there too.

data.title: Technical assessment of OpenTK revival vs. switching to SDL2
data.body:
So I and others have been advocating reviving OpenTK several times and I'm happy to hear that the MonoGame core team is making good progress on that front (https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/1528).

Now I hear @flibitijibibo has been working on porting MonoGame to SDL2 with apparently good results. From what he says on Twitter (I hope I'm not misrepresenting what he meant), SDL2 is well maintained and works great on all desktop platforms.

Apparently he mentioned his fork a couple times around here but it wasn't seriously considered because it's a huge change and the perceived cost of merging seems high while the benefits haven't been made obvious

I'm opening this issue hoping that we can discuss the technical & community merits of switching to SDL2 vs. marching forward with the on-going revival on OpenTK.

@flibitijibibo care to point us to your fork, detail what state it's in and how it compares in terms of features/bugs to the current MonoGame?

cc @tomspilman @dellis1972 @CartBlanche

data.title: Does KeyboardInputView need to scroll?
data.body:
Around line 204 of KeyboardInputView.cs, there's some code that attempts to scroll the "viewable" part after a keyboard has been shown/dismissed.

I've got a couple of questions about this.

First off, I'm not even sure this is correct. It doesn't look like this is proper usage of ScrollRectToVisible.

More importantly, do we need to do this at all? If we're trying to emulate WP7's behavior, there shouldn't be any scrolling at all. If I recall correctly, attempting to write too much text in the screen shown from Guide.ShowKeyboard() results in the text being truncated by an ellipsis.

We had the problem in our game of the Title/description disappearing from view a little bit after the keyboard was shown, and not returning until it was hidden. It's being scrolled offscreen. When we show the keyboard, we shouldn't need to do any kind of scrolling or readjusting, because the title of the page plus the length/width of the description text should never violate the bounds of the soft keyboard being shown.

Wanted to get a bit of discussion on removing this before getting a PR in, as I've only dabbled in the KeyboardView code and may be overlooking something.

data.title: Reorginization Of The Test Folder
data.body:
This is a cleanup pass trying to make sense of the test folder and what is there.  The change is very simple:
- The tests for `MonoGame.Framework` code are now under Framework folder.
- The support classes used to execute and validated the tests under the Runner folder.
- Fixed the project files to output to platform specific intermediate and output folders.

All this makes is much simpler to figure out what is what at a high level.

If you compare the folder now:

https://github.com/SickheadGames/MonoGame/tree/testfix/Test

To how it used to look:

https://github.com/SickheadGames/MonoGame/tree/develop/Test

It is much improved... but maybe still needs more cleanup.

First I debated renaming the "Framework" folder to maybe "MonoGame.Framework.Test" to make it clearer that this is where tests for the `MonoGame.Framework` namespace should be.  But if we would do that maybe that should be moved to the top level of the repo to be parallel to the "MonoGame.Framework" folder?

I know the Info.plist file is used for iOS, but I didn't know if it was safe to move it under the "Runner/iOS" folder with the rest of the platform specific stuff.  Anyone else know?

I'll submit a separate PR to cleanup the namespaces which were not fixed as part of this reorganization pass.

data.title: Automated Audio Testing

milestone.title: 4.0 Release
milestone.description: Major new API to support the new graphics libraries like Metal, Vulkan, and DirectX 12.

data.body:
We need to design and implement a method for automating testing of the sound effect and music system in MonoGame.  This system will work under the existing [testing framework](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/tree/develop/Test) and make it simple to write individual audio tests.

We need a system that works similar to how the graphics testing currently works.  We need it to actually play audio and we need to test the results against a known good output.  We cannot and should not use [mocking](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mock_object) which only test the API and not the actual results... providing limited benefits.

This GDC 2012 presentation outlines the basic approach we should take:

[Automated Audio Testing](http://twvideo01.ubm-us.net/o1/vault/gdc2012/slides/Audio%20Track/Rodrigue_Bernard_AutomatedAudioTesting.pdf)

Things we would need to develop:
- NUnit TestFixture for running SoundEffect and MediaPlayer tests.
- A method for recording the audio output from the TestFixture.
- A diff method which can compare two recordings and spot significant differences.

In particular recording the output on phone/gaming devices could be difficult as compared to desktop platforms.  We will have to take that issue one step at a time.

data.title: Contribution standards and PlayStation Mobile
data.body:
The contribution guidelines seem to state a bunch of requirements that have not been historically followed for MonoGame's Playstation Mobile support. I have numerous bug fixes and improvements in my fork aimed at making the PSM support more usable; how can I actually go about contributing these given that the PSM support is thoroughly in violation of the guidelines?

I can't find any unit tests for the PSM support, and it's already broken in numerous ways that suggest it never had any tests to begin with. I would love to offer published projects that demonstrate the features, but I do not own the IP rights to either of my current projects.
The file layout for PSM does not seem to match the file layout guidelines either.
What does 'pair verification' mean in practice? Is this possible for PSM at present (i.e. are there two MonoGame maintainers who actually own PSM publishing licenses necessary to test on devices, and own devices that can run PSM games)?

data.title: GraphicsDevice needs to be abstract or inherit from an interface so it can be mocked
data.body:
We write a lot of platform-agnostic unit tests, and MonoGame is _much_ more compatible than Unity was with dynamic mocking frameworks like moq. As a result, our developers are much more productive since they can do more testing in their native development environment with no packaging/publishing delays.

That being said, we ran into an instance where we needed to test our classes' interaction with GraphicsDevice, but couldn't mock GraphicsDevice because it didn't derive from an abstract or interface type (unlike IGraphicsDeviceManager, etc).

It would be great if an interface could be extracted and parameterized everywhere (like the Texture2D ctor). Even better would be if Texture2D was itself mockable.

Thanks!

data.title: Fire and Forget SoundEffect Playback
data.body:
I would like to see a fire-and-forget SoundEffect.Play implementation. The current implementation will playback sound effects immediately, which is not how Microsoft XNA implements sound effect playback.

Marking this for performance because it will improve the reliability of sound effect playback using OpenAL when games attempt to play back sound effects in worker threads. While not a supported feature, this will be a direction for the future of MonoGame.

(milestone MonoGame 3.2)
